newsitem.title: FRANCE: French business leader urges a slimmer state.
newsitem.headline: French business leader urges a slimmer state.

text.p: Jean Gandois, the chairman of France's employers' federation CNPF, called on Monday for a slimmer state focused on "essential missions."
Gandois, in a speech to business leaders in the southern city of Toulouse, also reaffirmed his support for European monetary union and smaller public and social welfare deficits.

"The state must stop spreading itself thin and instead must refocus its efforts on its essential role. Its most important tasks are not insignificant -- to educate, administer justice, assure public safety inside and outside of the country and protect against the most serious harm caused by social exclusion," he said.

"The rest should be up to individuals and business to undertake. There is no other solution," Gandois said. "All those who believe that the state can protect its citizens against the winds of competition are mistaken."

The speech, delivered just weeks ahead of France's May 25-June 1 parliamentary election, appeared to mirror recent statements by President Jacques Chirac also urging a smaller role for the French state.
But Gandois insisted that his "personal convictions ... should not be mistaken for political positions."
"There is no question of my being converted to a particular ideology, whichever that might be," he said.
